posts.description: Sunrise at Mesa Arch can be quite a show with a cozy audience, don't forget the popcorn.

While taking in the view from the top of Whistler, (and this photo) I found myself in conversation with a guy who must have been in his mid seventies. By the size of his white beard, it was most likely Santa Clause on spring break. He raved about how good the skiing, and the partying was. I don't know what Elfin magic he was on, but I'm pretty sure it included a fair portion of stoke, the universal elixir.

Shot at 300mm on the magic stability machine: @getolympus  e-m1 mark ii #capturingwhistler

Early morning among the spirits of the coast. LaPush is Magic. I’m excited to announce that @delightfulpursuits has invited me to teach alongside 5 amazing northwest photographers (tagged here) at a workshop in La Push, on May 20th. Join us as we cover a variety of fun subjects. I’m looking forward to sharing my thoughts on composition and designing an image to tell a story. For more details, visit DelightfulPursuits.com.
.
Also - For a chance to win a free spot, tag 3 friends in a comment below, and in a new post tag #LaPushCollabWorkshop explaining why you’d be interested in joining.

Nighttime on the Brandywine. I've been thinking about the relationship between photography and painting. With the brush we pull forward detail and clarity, we enhance the subject of our opinion, we build as tho with clay. However, with a camera - and its powerfully indiscriminate clarity, we have to push or crop areas into obscurity, as tho carving to reveal our subjects from the marble of the world. The fun of being digital, is we get to do both... @getolympus #capturingWhistler with the e-m1 mark ii
Some of my favorite adventures have started with a general premise, like "let's go north." The serendipity of specifics unfold along the way.

I learned to draw lines with pencil on paper about the same time as skis on snow. Often the two feel interchangeable. The gravity of a curve, transitions and flow.

Shooting with the @getolympus e-m1 mark ii, image stabilization, and a 600mm (equivalent) lens, it was a joy to let the mind fly where feet could not.

#capturingWhistler.

We went into the dunes before dawn. Soft cool sand sifting quietly beneath bare feet. As the sun rose, it warmed the valley, and out of the hills came the wind; gathering grains tumbled and turned. At each dune crest, a shimmering layer of light appeared rolling to the horizon; whitecaps on the slowest of seas.

While the forecast called for clear skies, the mountains had other plans. Thanks to the intrepid snow cave builders and tent chillers of #WinterTribeMeetup for the warm vibes.  Cheers to @moonmountainman for motivating a very cool event, and @adventurederrick for having such a well composed tent.

Kintsugi: The art of mending broken pottery with lacquer and gold; honoring the place of breaking as that of value... The Salt Flats were covered in a thin veil. From a distance others appeared to walk on clouds, yet beneath ones own feet was a cracked and broken surface. Sometimes the flaws revealed by closeness, also hold the beauty. Model: @jillyfish831 Dress: Goodwill

Chiaroscuro... Some of my strongest childhood memories are of light. Lying beneath a window, swimming hands between the glittering stars of dust and darkness. Squinting into nightlights, watching distortion flare among sleepy lashes. What a boring world it would be if everything were well lit and safe. I don't think we want a utopia, I think we want to keep growing: materially, spirituality, intellectually. Sometimes you need a little contrast to know in which direction the light shines.

Some snow globes shake themselves. We traveled on to make memorable turns, but part of me could have stayed right here, fully content.
Hokkaido with @westcomb

After ten years away from skiing, my tenth day back was a good one. During this time, while waves replaced slopes, ski technology was steadily advancing. The shot above might be the exact moment I blasted out of my Rip Van Winkle time warp; miraculously wearing some bomber @Westcomb gear and riding a @dynafit touring setup. Life is rad, and Its been cool to partner with companies that have kept pace far better than I. .
Huge thanks to @scott_kranz for leading the Hokkaido charge, and @gophersnipe for borrowing my camera and putting me in the cross hairs on this one.

Japan is a powerful place. Over the past week I partnered with @westcomb to explore the north island of Hokkaido, and test some of their impressive new ski gear. We dodged volcanoes, were blown from high ridges, soaked in hot springs, and scored some incredibly deep snow. The experience gave me feelings for how the landscape, the people, and the culture, weave together; creating a tapestry of beauty, civility and unquestionable strength. I'm already wondering how to get back.
There is something about being on the water at dusk; rather than under the sky, you are within it.
Sidetracked on side roads, floating somewhere between the ocean and Idaho.

Wandering at dusk, with loosely intended destination, I stumbled upon a tree in conversation with the moon. They both seemed to say "the more you play with us, the more we'll play with you." Wandering into the new year much the same way; I wish you all the best reflections from the world, of that which you've given to it.
An unforgettable adventure under a favorite coastline. Uploading photos to my website, and happy to liberate a few from square. @chelseakauai graceful as ever underwater.
